text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A general view southward from same. Downtown Manhattan is on the right; Bedloes Island and its Statue of Liberty in the center and Governors Island (with its rotund "Castle William") to the left. In the foreground is a ferry boat preparing to dock at the ferry house at the foot of Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

1894

J. S. Johnston, photo
Copyright 1894
Ewing Galloway
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]

text:
Fulton Street, east from Joralemon Street. At the right, on Joralemon Street, are the King's County Court House and the Hall of Records, followed by the King's County Trust Co. At the left, the Citizen Building houses the "Brooklyn Daily Citizen". The Boerum Place station of the Fulton Street elevated lines may also be seen.

About 1900.

Fulton Street, at its intersection with Joralemon, Adams and Willoughby Streets, showing the Fulton Street Elevated line of the B.M.T. The center building is the City Hall, with the Brooklyn Citizen's Bank Building on the left.

About 1910.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Joralemon Street, south side, at Fulton Street. A view of Kings County Court.
1910.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Fulton Street (elevated structure thereon), south side, east from its intersection with Joralemon Street, showing a general view southeastward as seen from the Temple Bar Building which is located on the west side of Court Street (No. 44) at the N.W. corner of Joralemon Street. At the right of the Fulton Street Elevated line, beginning with the foreground, are in their order, the following buildings; namely, the new and old Municipal Buildings, and the Hall of Records. The triangular roofed building to the left is at the intersection of Willoughby and Fulton Streets. The elevated station is on Boerum Place.
May 1926.

Brown Brothers.

Adams Street, west side, south to Fulton Street, from 366 at right foreground. In the background, is seen the Fulton Street "Elevated" structure, and the Hall of Records building; to the right of them, is a building occupied by the "Brooklyn Daily Citizen", established in 1836. It was built by one Jones in 1842, and was the first home of the N. Y. & N. J. Telephone Co., of Brooklyn.

1928.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Joralemon Street, south side, from but not including Boerum Place, to but not including Court Street. The view shown is the Brooklyn Municipal Building. In the background, is the upper part of the Chamber of Commerce Building, at 66 Court Street.

About 1930.

Ewing Galloway.

Joralemon Street, west from, but not including Boerum Place. On the right is shown the Borough Hall Building.

About 1930.

Ewing Galloway.

East River at the foot of Fulton Street, as seen from the Brooklyn Bridge and viewed southward. Next to the shore line is a roadway (no name) which extends south to Atlantic Basin. In the foreground may be seen the fire boat Abram S. Hewitt.

July 31, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River - Fulton Street - Brooklyn Bridge.
Fulton Street at Joralemon Street, to , Brooklyn
